critique: This executive order pertains to public health and communicable diseases. It specifies certain diseases for regulations related to apprehension, detention, or conditional release of individuals to prevent the spread of suspected communicable diseases. It assigns presidential functions under sections 362 and 364(a) of the Public Health Service Act to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. It also revokes Executive Order 12452. There's no clear indication of a liberal or conservative ideological tilt. The order doesn't directly address immigration. It could be argued that it expands executive power by assigning presidential functions to the Secretary, but it also limits it by specifying that the order doesn't create any enforceable right or benefit. It centralizes authority at the federal level. It prioritizes national security by aiming to prevent the spread of communicable diseases. It involves government intervention in public health matters. It doesn't directly address social inclusion.
